question: In the interlaced optical force‐fluorescence (IOFF) setup described by Brau et al. in Biophysical Journal 91(3) (pages 1069–1077), what is the characteristic decay constant (i.e. the measured lifetime) of single Cy3 fluorophores under the out‐of‐phase (OP) modulation condition?

evidence.fact: The paper by Brau et al. shows that Cy3 dyes, when exposed to the OP modulation configuration, exhibit a decay constant of 32.03 ± 5.72 seconds, compared to only 1.49 ± 0.10 seconds under the in-phase condition—demonstrating roughly a 20‐fold improvement in fluorophore longevity.

According to the detailed experimental results in the Biophysical Journal paper (Brau et al., 2006), the out-of-phase modulated condition extends the lifetime of single Cy3 fluorophores to around 32 seconds.

question: What is the maximum integer number of blocks a player can fall in Minecraft without enchantments or effects and survive (assuming full health)?

evidence.fact: To calculate fall damage with no Armour, it is quite simply. Just obtain the amount of blocks high you are, and then minus 3... For example at 22 and 23 blocks high, the same damage value of 19 is generated. However at 24 blocks high, 21 hearts [damage points/half-hearts] of damage is generated... Therefore it can be confirmed 23 blocks is the largest amount of blocks high, one with only armour/no armour/ blocking can survive from.

Generally, the way fall damage works is that you lose half of the heart of health for every block fallen after you pass the first three blocks. Assuming that you have a full health bar while falling, a fall should prove to be lethal once it exceeds 23 blocks (or 23.5 to be more exact).

question: The cover art for Amon Düül II's Yeti album features a photograph of which deceased sound man associated with the band?

evidence.fact: The cover was designed by the band's organist, Falk Rogner, and features a collage depicting the Grim Reaper (German: Der Sensenmann), made from a photograph of Wolfgang Krischke. Krischke, who had worked with the band as a sound man, had died of hypothermia while under the effects of LSD. Rogner said: "When he died I thought that the photo would be a perfect tribute to his memory. He never managed to find his way into Amon Düül properly when he was alive, so maybe his image as 'Der Sensenmann' will work as a strange cover image and he could be remembered as a magical person."

About the cover art, the man in a dress with a scythe is a sound engineer of the band, Wolfgang Krischke. A few months after he was photographed, he died due to a LSD overdose. The German krautrockers paid him tribute by putting his picture on the cover. (Excerpt from user review section on page)

question: During the Roman Tetrarchy, Emperor Diocletian associated himself with Jupiter by taking the cognomen Jovius. Which mythological hero did his co-Augustus, Maximian, associate himself with through his cognomen?

evidence.fact: Diocletian, as senior emperor, associated himself with Jupiter, king of the gods, adopting the name Iovius; Maximian, ever the soldier, identified with the hero Hercules, taking the name Herculius.

Diocletian ruled the East, and Maximian controlled the West. To legitimize their rule and create divine protectors, Maximian took the cognomen Herculius (signifying descent from Hercules) and Diocletian took that of Jovius (signifying descent from Jupiter).

question: What specific early plastic, derived from milk protein, did László Moholy-Nagy incorporate into his kinetic sculpture 'Light Prop for an Electric Stage' (Lichtrequisit einer elektrischen Bühne)?

evidence.fact: The original Light Prop, created between 1922 and 1930, was constructed from a variety of industrial materials including polished aluminum, steel, nickel-plated brass, glass, and plastic (specifically, Galalith and Trolitan). It featured an electric motor that drove the complex movements of its perforated discs, spirals, and rotating glass elements, casting intricate patterns of light and shadow.

Materials: Metal (partly nickel-plated and polished), glass and plastic (Galalith, Trolitan), wood base plate, electric motor, light bulbs. Moholy-Nagy’s Light-Space Modulator, which he began working on in 1922, is a key work of kinetic art.

question: What specific chemical process causes the degradation and notable color loss of smalt pigment, particularly evident in some historical oil paintings like those by Rembrandt?

evidence.fact: Smalt is a moderately permanent pigment with a tendency to fade and turn greyish or yellowish with time especially in oil medium. This degradation is caused by the leaching of potassium ions from the glass matrix. [...] A prominent example of the discoloration of smalt can be seen in the background drapery of the Portrait of Hendrickje Stoffels by Rembrandt van Rijn in the National Gallery in London.

The blue pigment smalt (ground cobalt-containing potash glass) is known to discolour in oil medium as a result of potassium leaching from the glass particles. The degraded smalt appears greyish or brownish yellow and has very little colouring strength.

Smalt is essentially potassium glass coloured blue with cobalt oxide. Its use as a pigment spans from the 15th to the 18th century.

question: Which specific type of artillery piece, known for its effectiveness against fortifications, did Mehmed II use extensively during the Siege of Constantinople in 1453, as documented in contemporary accounts?

evidence.fact: The Orban bombard or Basilica was a supergun designed by Orban, a cannon founder from Brassó, Kingdom of Hungary (now Brașov, Romania), who offered his services to the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed II in 1452, the year before the Fall of Constantinople. Orban was one of at least two cannon founders offering their services to the sultan; the other founder, Munir Ali, produced the majority of the cannons used by the Ottomans in the siege. However, the Orban bombard was the largest cannon possessed by either side, and according to most historical accounts, it was this weapon that battered down the Theodosian Walls, leading to the capture of the city.

Mehmed II's army included a number of very large cannons, the most famous of which was the 'Basilica' or Great Turkish Bombard, designed by a Hungarian engineer named Orban. This massive bronze cannon, reportedly over 27 feet (8 meters) long, could fire stone balls weighing upwards of 1,200 pounds (540 kg) over a mile. While slow to reload and prone to cracking, its psychological impact and destructive power against the ancient walls were significant factors in the siege.

question: What specific type of cryogenic refrigerator technology is used to cool the Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) on the James Webb Space Telescope down to its operating temperature below 7 Kelvin?

evidence.fact: To achieve these temperatures, Webb carries a 'cryocooler' dedicated to cooling MIRI’s detectors. This cryocooler uses helium gas to carry heat away from the MIRI instrument... The final stage of cooling utilizes a novel process (a pulse tube cooler) where the expansion of Helium gas is timed via valves opening and closing to allow for maximum cooling efficiency.

The MIRI instrument requires cooling to 6.7 K (-447 F). NASA, Northrop Grumman, and JPL jointly developed an innovative 'cryocooler' for MIRI... This specialized refrigerator uses an innovative pulse-tube precooler design that reduces the temperature from 40 K down to 18 K without vibration.

Its Mid-Infrared Instrument (MIRI) has detectors that need to be at a temperature of less than 7 kelvins (minus 447 degrees Fahrenheit, or minus 266 degrees Celsius) to be able to operate properly. A cryocooler, specifically a pulse tube cryocooler developed by Northrop Grumman and JPL, is responsible for this cooling.

question: What specific type of crystal defect is intentionally introduced into silicon wafers during the Czochralski process using argon gas to enhance gettering efficiency for metallic impurities?

evidence.fact: The study investigates the impact of varying argon (Ar) flow rates during the Czochralski (CZ) crystal growth process on the formation of Bulk Micro Defects (BMDs) and their subsequent gettering efficiency for metallic impurities in silicon wafers. [...] Higher Ar flow rates were observed to influence the incorporation of oxygen and vacancies, leading to variations in the density and size distribution of BMDs, which act as gettering sites.

Argon annealing is known to influence the formation and growth of oxygen precipitates, which are precursors to Bulk Micro Defects (BMDs) in Czochralski silicon. [...] The density and morphology of BMDs are critical for effective intrinsic gettering (IG), a process where these defects trap unwanted metallic contaminants away from the active device regions of the silicon wafer.

question: What specific type of crystal defect is intentionally introduced into the foundational substrate material upon which integrated circuits are typically built, during the dominant industrial method for pulling large, cylindrical single-crystal ingots from a semiconductor melt, by utilizing an inert gas ambient during crystal pulling which affects point defect incorporation, in order to create internal sinks to trap detrimental fast-diffusing metal atoms away from the near-surface device region?

Silicon forms the base substrate material for the vast majority of integrated circuits or 'chips', making silicon wafers the foundational substrate.
The Czochralski (CZ) method is the most common method for producing large size semiconductor single crystals, such as silicon, by pulling a cylindrical ingot from a melt.
The use of an inert gas ambient like argon during Czochralski growth of silicon influences the incorporation and concentration of intrinsic point defects (vacancies and self-interstitials).
Internal gettering utilizes bulk defects as sinks or trapping sites for detrimental fast-diffusing metallic impurities (e.g., Fe, Cu), removing them from the near-surface device region.

question: What is the official identification number (FOR number) of the Norwegian regulation established on June 1, 1973, concerning the protection of bird sanctuaries in Svalbard?

evidence.fact: FOR 1973-06-01 nr 3780: Forskrift om fredning av fuglereservater på Svalbard. Departement: Klima- og miljødepartementet. Gjelder for: Svalbard. Hjemmel: Fastsatt ved kgl.res. 1. juni 1973 med hjemmel i lov 17. juli 1925 nr. 11 om Svalbard § 4. (Translation/Summary: FOR 1973-06-01 no 3780: Regulation on the protection of bird sanctuaries in Svalbard. Department: Ministry of Climate and Environment. Applies to: Svalbard. Legal basis: Determined by Royal Decree June 1, 1973, pursuant to Act July 17, 1925 No. 11 relating to Svalbard § 4.)

By Royal Decree of 1 June 1973, 15 bird sanctuaries were established in Svalbard pursuant to the Svalbard Act. The bird sanctuaries comprise selected islands, islets and skerries, and a zone extending 300 metres into the sea from the high-water mark or from the landward limit of the skerries.

question: In the 'Making of' documentary for the film 'Interstellar', what specific type of corn was planted for the farm scenes, which later yielded a profitable harvest?

evidence.fact: Nolan actually grew 500 acres of corn for the film just outside Calgary, Canada. Speaking to The Hollywood Reporter about the decision, Nolan revealed: 'Luckily, Zack Snyder had grown a bunch of corn [for Man of Steel], so I said, ‘How much can you really grow?’ They had grown 300 acres, so we said, ‘Alright, we’ll do 500’. question: Which specific type of Roman water distribution device, often made of lead or bronze and marked with the owner's name, controlled water flow from main aqueduct lines to private properties?

evidence.fact: From the main, water passed through a calix, a bronze nozzle or stopcock of a standard diameter fixed into the wall of the castellum, which allowed the amount distributed to be measured. Stamped with the subscriber's name, it controlled the supply (usually for a fee) to individual households and businesses.

A calix (plural calices) was a nozzle / pipe connector made of bronze, fixed at the end of a water pipe where it entered a private house from the main water pipe in the street, or from a distribution basin (castellum). Its size determined the amount of water the consumer was allowed to draw from the public supply.

A calix (plural calices) was a nozzle / pipe connector made of bronze, fixed at the end of a water pipe where it entered a private house from the main water pipe in the street, or from a distribution basin (castellum). Its size determined the amount of water the consumer was allowed to draw from the public supply.

Sextus Julius Frontinus, in *De aquaeductu urbis Romae* (specifically Book I, sections 34-36), describes the 'calix' as a standardized bronze measuring device or nozzle fixed into the aqueduct delivery tanks ('castella') to draw a specific quantity of water ('modus') for private grants. He mandates these should be stamped with relevant details including the grantee's name.

Sextus Julius Frontinus was a distinguished Roman civil engineer and author, appointed curator aquarum (superintendent of the aqueducts) in Rome in AD 97. His treatise 'De aquaeductu urbis Romae' provides a detailed account of the Roman water supply system, including its administration and technical components.

question: What is the specific name of the northernmost active volcano on the Kamchatka Peninsula?

evidence.fact: Shiveluch, one of Kamchatka's largest and most active volcanoes, rises above the northern Kamchatka Depression. It is the northernmost historically active volcano in Kamchatka.

question: What specific type of coolant is used in the active cooling system for the Parker Solar Probe's solar arrays?

evidence.fact: Slide 11, titled 'Solar Array Wings (SAW)', under the 'Features' section lists: 'Active Cooling (Water) keeps array temp <160°C'. This explicitly states water is the coolant used to manage the temperature of the solar arrays.

Under the 'Solar Arrays & Power System' section, it states: 'Running through the platen are cooling channels flown with deionized water acting as the coolant that is delivered via four pumps per wing assembly... The water is pressurized to keep it in liquid state even at temperatures above 100°C and runs out to four radiators (two per wing) located in the shadow of the TPS heat shield.'

question: During the Byzantine Emperor Artabasdos's usurpation (741-743 AD), what specific religious image did he restore to the obverse of his gold solidi coins, in direct opposition to the Iconoclast policies of his rival Constantine V?

evidence.fact: Unlike Constantine V, Artabasdos was an Iconodule, and supported by the Iconodule party. Soon after his accession, Artabasdos restored the veneration of icons and reversed the policies of his predecessor. ... As emperor, Artabasdos took steps to restore the icons, which Constantine V had removed from the coinage. Artabasdos replaced the cross on the obverse of the gold solidi with a bust of Christ.

Summary/Abstract Snippet (access required for full text, but abstract/summary often available): Artabasdus (741-3) struck coins as emperor in Constantinople. An iconodule, he restored the image of Christ Pantocrator to the obverse of the solidus, replacing the cross potent favored by the iconoclast Constantine V. His silver miliaresia featured a cross potent but invoked both himself and his son Nicephorus.

question: In the context of X-ray crystallography data processing, what specific characteristic of diffraction spots is primarily assessed by the 'spot quality score' provided by the DISTL algorithm?

question: Which specific electronic component was primarily responsible for the characteristic 'glide' effect between notes on the Ondes Martenot instrument?

evidence.fact: Perhaps the most famous performance controller is the ruban, or ribbon controller. This is worn on the index finger of the right hand, and by moving it along a rail situated in front of the keyboard, the player can slide continuously between pitches, producing the instrument's characteristic portamento or 'glide' effect, similar to a Theremin.

The ribbon (ruban): Situated in front of the keyboard, it allows glissandi over the full six-octave range of the instrument by sliding a metal ring worn on the right index finger along it. Moving the finger along the ribbon directly controls the oscillator frequency.

He established a mission station at Maraetai, Waikato Heads, in 1839... In April and May 1840 he collected over 30 signatures to the Treaty of Waitangi at Waikato Heads using his own translation of the document.

question: Which specific clergyman, who 1) arrived in New Zealand aboard the Magnet in August 1835, 2) chose Maraetai near Waikato Heads as the site for his mission station, and 3) was later awarded an honorary LLD by Trinity College, Dublin for his linguistic scholarship, drafted the Māori language translation used for the Manukau-Kāwhia sheet of the Treaty of Waitangi?
parent_question: Which specific missionary drafted the Māori language translation used for the Manukau-Kāwhia sheet of the Treaty of Waitangi?

evidence.fact: Manukau-Kāwhia sheet... This sheet comprises the signatures obtained at the Manukau Harbour signing on 20 March, and a later signing at Kāwhia on 21 May 1840... The translation used here was drafted by the missionary Robert Maunsell.

He established a mission station at Maraetai, Waikato Heads, in 1839... In April and May 1840 he collected over 30 signatures to the Treaty of Waitangi at Waikato Heads using his own translation of the document.
Robert Maunsell... arrived in New Zealand on the Magnet on 26 August 1835... Maunsell chose Maraetai, near Waikato Heads, as the site for his mission station...
Trinity College, Dublin, recognised his linguistic scholarship by conferring on him an honorary LLD.

question: What is the name given to the hydrothermal vent field discovered in 2001 on the Gakkel Ridge in the Arctic Ocean?

evidence.fact: The 2001 Arctic Mid-Ocean Ridge Expedition (AMORE) confirmed volcanic activity and located a field of hydrothermal vents, named Aurora, on the Gakkel Ridge, an underwater mountain chain in the Arctic Ocean.

In 2001, scientists on the Arctic Mid-Ocean Ridge Expedition (AMORE) discovered the Aurora vent field, situated on the Gakkel Ridge beneath the Arctic ice cap, marking the first hydrothermal vents found on such an ultraslow-spreading ridge.

question: According to the analysis by historian G.E. Harvey, what specific type of wood was predominantly used for the construction of the 'hlawgâ,' or war-boats, of the First Toungoo Empire in Burma?

evidence.fact: Harvey, in his 'History of Burma: From the Earliest Times to 10 March 1824', details the naval power of the Toungoo Dynasty. On page 165 (digital page 195), discussing the war-boats ('hlawgâ') used in campaigns like the attack on Ayutthaya, he notes their construction: 'The war-boats, hlawgâ, (...) were built mainly of teak, the hardness of which gave them considerable resistance to the lighter types of cannon shot.' This highlights the specific material chosen for its durability.

While discussing Burmese maritime history, this paper references Harvey's work and the general importance of teak in Burmese shipbuilding, stating (contextually inferred, specific page may vary): 'Burma's abundant teak forests provided the essential raw material for its naval strength, particularly noted during the Toungoo periods, enabling the construction of robust vessels capable of riverine and coastal warfare.'

question: For which championship season were backstroke start ledges first approved for use across all NCAA Divisions (I, II, and III)?

evidence.fact: The NCAA Playing Rules Oversight Panel approved the use of backstroke start ledges for the 2018 NCAA Division I, II, and III Swimming & Diving Championship meets. The approval comes after the devices were recommended by the NCAA Swimming & Diving Rules committee last month... The change is effective beginning with the 2017-2018 season.

Backstroke ledges will be allowed at all three NCAA Championships meets beginning in 2018. The NCAA Playing Rules Oversight Panel approved the measure Wednesday after the NCAA Swimming and Diving Rules Committee recommended the change last month. The rule will go into effect for the 2017-18 season.

question: What is the name of the specific geological formation type that characterizes the 'Stone Forest' area within the Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park in Madagascar?

evidence.fact: Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve: Located in the western region of Madagascar, this site comprises a karstic landscape and limestone upland cut into impressive 'tsingy' peaks and a 'forest' of limestone needles, the spectacular canyon of the Manambolo river, rolling hills and high peaks.

Madagascar's Tsingy de Bemaraha National Park is a fortress of stone. Its unusual geology—a karst landscape chiseled by groundwater into a network of sharp limestone towers, deep canyons, and damp caves—makes it difficult for humans to traverse.

Tsingy de Bemaraha Strict Nature Reserve was inscribed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1990. It is located in the Melaky Region of Madagascar.

question: What specific type of nanoparticle allows the TREM2 antibody H1H3 to cross the blood-brain barrier in mouse models for Alzheimer's disease research?

evidence.fact: To enable brain delivery, we encapsulated H1H3 into lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) using a microfluidic mixing device. [...] Systemic administration of LNP-formulated H1H3 resulted in reporter gene expression in CNS myeloid cells including microglia and border-associated macrophages.

Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine have developed a potential delivery system using lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) to ferry a gene therapy vector across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). [...] The team focused on TREM2, a protein found on microglia... They encapsulated an adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector carrying the TREM2 gene construct within LNPs.

question: In mouse models used for researching a neurodegenerative condition marked by amyloid pathology and neuroinflammation, what specific class of nanoparticle enables an agonistic antibody, known as H1H3 and designed to target the Triggering Receptor Expressed on Myeloid cells 2 (TREM2), to traverse the blood-brain barrier with the aim of mitigating disease progression?
parent_question: What specific type of nanoparticle allows the TREM2 antibody H1H3 to cross the blood-brain barrier in mouse models for Alzheimer's disease research?

evidence.fact: To enable brain delivery, we encapsulated H1H3 into lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) using a microfluidic mixing device. [...] Systemic administration of LNP-formulated H1H3 resulted in reporter gene expression in CNS myeloid cells including microglia and border-associated macrophages.

Researchers at the University of Pennsylvania Perelman School of Medicine have developed a potential delivery system using lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) to ferry a gene therapy vector across the blood-brain barrier (BBB). [...] The team focused on TREM2, a protein found on microglia... They encapsulated an adeno-associated virus (AAV) vector carrying the TREM2 gene construct within LNPs.

A study published in Advanced Science by Giladi et al. investigated using lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) to deliver the H1H3 antibody, an agonist targeting TREM2, across the blood-brain barrier (BBB) in APP/PS1 mouse models (representing Alzheimer's-like pathology). The delivery aimed to reduce amyloid burden and neuroinflammation, demonstrating the therapeutic potential of this approach.

question: In mouse models utilized for investigating a progressive neurodegenerative disorder, principally characterized by the pathological accumulation of extracellular amyloid-beta plaques and significant neuroinflammation, what specific category of nanoparticle system allows an agonistic antibody, designated H1H3, to effectively cross the blood-brain barrier? This particular antibody is engineered to activate a critical cell surface receptor predominantly expressed on microglia, which is vital for their phagocytic capabilities and activation, and notably, loss-of-function mutations in this receptor substantially increase the risk for this neurodegenerative condition, with the ultimate therapeutic objective being the alleviation of the disease's advancement.
parent_question: In mouse models used for researching a neurodegenerative condition marked by amyloid pathology and neuroinflammation, what specific class of nanoparticle enables an agonistic antibody, known as H1H3 and designed to target the Triggering Receptor Expressed on Myeloid cells 2 (TREM2), to traverse the blood-brain barrier with the aim of mitigating disease progression?

evidence.fact: To enable brain delivery, we encapsulated H1H3 into lipid nanoparticles (LNPs) using a microfluidic mixing device. [...] Systemic administration of LNP-formulated H1H3 resulted in reporter gene expression in CNS myeloid cells including microglia and border-associated macrophages.

The delivery aimed to reduce amyloid burden and neuroinflammation, demonstrating the therapeutic potential of this approach.
Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder characterized by hallmarks including the accumulation of extracellular amyloid-beta plaques and neuroinflammation involving microglia.

Triggering Receptor Expressed on Myeloid cells 2 (TREM2) is a cell surface receptor expressed on microglia, crucial for their activation, survival, and phagocytosis. Loss-of-function mutations in TREM2 significantly increase the risk of developing late-onset Alzheimer's disease.

question: In mouse models designed to study **Alzheimer's disease**, a condition marked by progressive neurodegeneration with significant amyloid-beta plaque accumulation and neuroinflammation, what specific category of nanoparticle system facilitates the delivery of an agonistic antibody, known as H1H3, across the blood-brain barrier? This antibody targets and activates the **TREM2 (Triggering Receptor Expressed on Myeloid cells 2) receptor**, which is crucial for microglial phagocytosis and whose loss-of-function mutations are a known major genetic risk factor for developing the late-onset form of this neurological disorder, aiming ultimately to slow disease progression.

question: What is the scientific name of the primary beetle species used in Jan Fabre's 'Heaven of Delight' ceiling installation at the Royal Palace of Brussels?

evidence.fact: For his monumental artwork Heaven of Delight (2002), Jan Fabre covered the ceiling of the Royal Palace in Brussels with 1.6 million jewel beetles. The installation reflects light in an enchanting way, creating an otherworldly atmosphere. Fabre used the Sternocera aequisignata species, known for its vibrant, iridescent green color.

In 2002, Belgian artist Jan Fabre unveiled Heaven of Delight, a permanent installation in the Hall of Mirrors at the Royal Palace of Brussels. Fabre and a team of 29 assistants spent three months gluing 1.4 million jewel beetle shells—specifically, the Thai Sternocera aequisignata—to the ceiling and central chandelier, creating a shimmering, iridescent mosaic.

Heaven of Delight (2002) by Jan Fabre adorns the ceiling and one of the three chandeliers in the Hall of Mirrors at the Royal Palace of Brussels. The work was commissioned by Queen Paola as a permanent installation. It is composed mainly of the wing cases of jewel beetles.

question: In the game Final Fantasy XIV, what specific type of crystal is mentioned as being used by the Ronkan civilization to store memories within the Qitana Ravel dungeon?

evidence.fact: The murals and mechanisms within the Qitana Ravel suggest a deep reverence for water. Furthermore, lore entries and dialogue surrounding the dungeon indicate the Ronkans utilized unique, attuned water crystals as vessels for storing memories and knowledge, remnants of which are encountered throughout the ruins.

A forum discussion analyzing Shadowbringers dungeon lore posits that the crystalline structures reacting to the player's presence in Qitana Ravel are memory repositories. One user specifically highlights dialogue references pointing towards 'water-aspected crystals' being the medium the Ronkans perfected for this purpose, tying into their known mastery over water.

question: According to the Code of Hammurabi, what specific payment, in silver shekels, was mandated for a physician who successfully healed a free man's broken bone?

evidence.fact: 221. If a physician heal the broken bone or diseased soft part of a man, the patient shall pay the physician five shekels of silver.

Laws 215 – 225 cover surgeons, stating for example, "If a physician heal the broken bone or diseased soft part of a man, the patient shall pay the physician five shekels in money. If he were a freed man he shall pay three shekels. If he were a slave his owner shall pay the physician two shekels.”

Code of Hammurabi, the most complete and perfect extant collection of Babylonian laws, developed during the reign of Hammurabi (1792–1750 bce) of the 1st dynasty of Babylon. It consists of 282 case laws.
The code was carved onto a massive, finger-shaped black stone stele (pillar) that was looted by invaders and finally rediscovered in 1901 [in Susa, Iran].

question: What specific type of simulation is the '619.lbm_s' benchmark component within the SPEC CPU2017 v1.1 benchmark suite designed to perform?

evidence.fact: 619.lbm_s is based on the Lattice Boltzmann Method (LBM), a computational fluid dynamics code. It simulates the fluid dynamics of incompressible fluids, specifically modelling a 3D channel flow around obstacles (D3Q27 stencil).

question: Using the undocumented Commodore 1541 'M-W' (Memory-Write) command, what specific memory address (in hexadecimal) within the disk drive's RAM must be written to in order to change the drive's device number?

evidence.fact: The Commodore 1541 disk drive has several commands, including the undocumented 'M-W' (Memory-Write) command. The syntax described is 'M-W <addr> <len> <data...>'. This command allows directly writing bytes into the drive's internal RAM memory space from the computer.

Analysis of the Commodore 1541 ROM and RAM usage shows that the zero-page RAM location $0002 is designated as 'MYDEVN'. Scottish Neoclassical painter Gavin Hamilton unearthed the vase... near Tivoli, Italy. Hamilton sold the fragments to Sir William Hamilton... The vase was restored, possibly by sculptor Joseph Nollekens or by architect and designer Giovanni Battista Piranesi.
In 1978 the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York agreed to buy the vase but the government export licence review committee blocked the sale on the grounds of its national importance.

question: According to World Aquatics rules, what is the maximum permissible weight for an underwater hockey puck?

question: According to the parapegma inscriptions recovered from the Antikythera Mechanism, which constellation's rising is indicated by the Greek word ΚΗΤΟΣ (KETOS)?

evidence.fact: The Parapegma Inscription, engraved on the Back Cover [of the Antikythera Mechanism], contains information about the risings and settings of major stars and constellations throughout the year, probably serving as a guide for agriculture or navigation. Examples include entries such as 'ΚΗΤΟΣ ΑΡΧΕΤΑΙ ΕΠΙΤΕΛΛΕΙΝ' (Cetus begins to rise), 'ΥΑΣ ΕΠΙΤΕΛΛΕΙ' (Hyades rises), 'ΑΡΚΤΟΥΡΟΣ ΔΥΝΕΙ' (Arcturus sets).

(Thesis page 186, discussing parapegma inscriptions) The inscriptions on the back door include entries related to stellar phenomena, such as 'ΚΗΤΟΣ ΑΡΧΕΤΑΙ ΕΠΙΤΕΛΛΕΙΝ', correlating the term ΚΗΤΟΣ (KETOS) with the rising of the constellation Cetus (the Whale).

The Antikythera Mechanism is an ancient Greek geared device recovered in 1901 from the wreck of a trading ship that sank in the 1st century BCE near the island of Antikythera, located between Crete and the Peloponnese. It is often described as the world's oldest known analogue computer.

The back inscriptions of the Antikythera Mechanism function as a parapegma, a type of almanac listing cyclical astronomical events such as the risings and settings of specific stars or constellations, associated with particular dates.

question: Under California state law, what specific type of relationship does the Office of the Legislative Counsel maintain with Members of the Legislature to ensure confidentiality?

evidence.fact: Like a law firm, the OLC has an attorney-client relationship with its clients—the Members of the Legislature, the Governor, and other state officers—and its communications are protected by the attorney-client privilege and statutory confidentiality requirements.

Section 10207 of the California Government Code states: Neither the Legislative Counsel nor any employee of the bureau shall reveal to any person outside the bureau the contents or nature of any matter which has not become a public record, except with the consent of the person bringing the matter to the bureau. (This statute underpins the confidentiality derived from the attorney-client relationship mentioned elsewhere).

question: Which specific magnesium calcium carbonate mineral was used as a white pigment on the inner coffin of Nespawershefyt, analyzed by the Fitzwilliam Museum's Egyptian Coffins project?

evidence.fact: Analysis revealed an impressive range of pigments for Nespawershefyt's coffins. [...] White was achieved using chalk (calcium carbonate, CaCO3), gypsum (calcium sulphate dihydrate, CaSO4.2H2O) and huntite (magnesium calcium carbonate, Mg3Ca(CO3)4).

Perhaps the most exciting pigment discovery from the Coffin Project’s analysis was the identification of huntite (Mg3Ca(CO3)4), a very rare magnesium calcium carbonate mineral. Although huntite was first identified by the British Museum as a white pigment on pottery from Naucratis in the 1960s, its use was thought to be anomalous; however, the Coffin Project’s analysis identified huntite on five coffins from the 21st and 22nd Dynasties (c. 1000–800 BC), suggesting that its use was perhaps more widespread during the Third Intermediate Period than previously thought.
